pros: You get to say you work for UPS which most people think is actually a good place to work and great company.
cons: You work for 30 years only to have them sell your division when you are days away from collecting your pension and they tell you "Sorry so close but no pension for you" The company is looking to get rid of many of its older employees to mitigate the pension liability. Imagine being days away from your Birthday and losing 60% of your pension because they sell UPS Freight and are not willing to bridge you after working over 30 years. Not a people company and don't care about family. Most Managers get demoted at some point regardless of work performance its just their way of cutting cost or creating new job openings for other suck ups. I thought it was all worth it for the pension so I put up with a lot of high pressure and stress only to have UPS Freight sold and lose most of what I earned. While UPS does not offer a pension anymore my warning is if they treat long time dedicated employees like this just think how they will treat new employees and management.

job_title: Aircraft Load Planner in Anchorage, AK
pros:
- Competitive wages.
- Benefits package.
- Tuition reimbursement after a year, attention to fine print.
cons:
-Culture encouraged finger pointing and blaming the next person, rather than taking personal accountability. This lead to time wasted documenting proof that a job was done rather than worrying about doing the job itself.
-Part timers have a low hour commitment with high availability requirement. There were mandated randomly assigned shifts outside my available hours. It was difficult to hold another job to supplement part time income.
-Insufficient/irrelevant onboarding training, and poor on the job training. You are often left to “fend for yourself”
-Very few advancement opportunities, almost no full time positions.
-Benefits package has odd clauses, as well as few in network options. Read the fine print carefully.

pros: easy and lenient hours if you just explain what's going on. Amazing benefits for what the job is. You will have a harder time if you aren't physical person, its a very labor intensive job. The pay started at 14.50 but as of right now on 11/15/2021 its 20 an hour and my local at least is trying to make it permanent. There is opportunity to work more hours, i was working an average of 36 hours a week making about 650 after taxes but that is very rare and only a handful of people are able to do what i did, there just isn't an opportunity unless you have more seniority or they quit. The chances of you being a driver especially right now are pretty good. Seasonal isnt bad. the opportunity to go into management is plentiful, moving up in management is another story, it can be difficult and take awhile but if you stick it out, theres plenty of money to be made and a good career.
cons: HARD work, you will sweat but you'll be healthy and in shape at the end of the day, the pay is decent as of right now but there is no guarantee of it either. if it goes back down to 14.5 that would make this job even harder as that isn't the minimum wage for places like McDonalds. management can be AWFUL, supervisors on power trips, full time supervisors act like they're god himself, they like to steal hours and work, they'll send you home and then unload a truck or two they were saving for later.

pros: The pay and the benefits.  Barely.   If one was to start their own business (doing anything) and work as hard as they do at UPS;  they could easily surpass the compensation package at UPS.
cons:
The micro management and incredibly heavy workload.  Most people who start working here today may not be able to make 25 years, let alone 30 years.  Hernias, knee replacements, hip replacements, carpel tunnel, tennis elbow, golfers elbow will all be on the rise due to the increased workload.  The number of stops and packages is at an all time high.  Management has literally walked on the backs of employees shoes as an intimidation tactic to force these drivers to work at an unsafe and unsustainable pace.  No integrity at the highest levels of management.
It is unfortunate but it is likely that at least 5 employees will suffer serious injury or death due to heat related illness within the next  3 months.

review_title: Good pay and benefits, out of touch corporate and upper management
job_title: Part Time Supervisor in Omaha, NE
pros: Pay is excellent as are the benefits. I started out at 18.45 and that was 3 years ago. They also offer tuition assistance. You get payed for 27.5 hours even if you only work 20.
cons: This is not a place/position you should make a career out of. Period. Full stop. While the starting pay is good raises barely keep up with inflation and are the same for everyone even if you have excellent performance. Yeah, that dude who's on his phone half the shift instead of managing his people is getting the same percent raise as the people busting their butt for the company. I could rant forever about how out of touch UPS corporate is about employees in one of the oldest buildings in the country meeting the same standards as much, much newer buildings but I won't. Suffice it to say this is great job if you're offered and you're working your way through college and need a job to pay the bills. Don't stick with this after college though.

job_title: Operations Management Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: Higher average pay if you're starting out. Part time job allows you to work elsewhere so you can make a decent living. Can work only seasonally if you prefer
cons:
You are expected to work overtime anytime they need it, especially in management. In a job that's supposed to be 27.5 hrs, I have worked over 40hrs against my will while my employer knew I was in college in finals week. They don't care about school, other work, or any other commitments you have in your life. You are expected to drop everything for the company, and on extremely short notice. I might find out at 9 pm (shift ends at 10:30pm) that they need me to stay until 2:30am or until I'm done. There is no work/life balance. You also lose your vacations and (essentially) free healthcare benefits when you become management because you are no longer backed by the union.

However, if you're planning to stay in the hub as an hourly employee, you have the union to back you up if you want more or less hours, or if you want to be in a particular place/position within the building. This is all seniority based, so if you start early in your career, you can work your way up over time. You also get the best healthcare a person can get (in my opinion) essentially for free. If you become a driver, you no longer have a good work-life balance (same thing as with management) but you make exponentially more money. So there are some options available to you.

review_title: High Stress Job With Little to No Work/Life Balance
pros:
Salary - Good pay starting out with a raise that goes into effect roughly 4-6 months into employment once training is completed.

Benefits - Company picks up the majority of the costs for health insurance, with some like short-term disability and a small life insurance completely covered by UPS. Many other options like long-term disability, dental, pet insurance and others.
cons:
Toxic Work Environment - Management is completely clueless on how to actually manage people. Takes a heavy handed and derogatory approach on handling employees.
 
Work/Life Balance - There is none. The company's view is there is nothing more important than their mission. If you have to work 15-18 hours a day, so be it.

Training - With COVID changing the way that companies need to operate, this one definitely needs to learn in a hurry. Was supposed to start with a one week, off-site training course that was shut down at the start of the pandemic. Management made little to no effort to adapt the training to the fact that someone new was coming in and not knowing what is going on. Training pretty much consisted of "Watch this training video. Now it's time for a face-to-face quiz. Why aren't you an expert on this, you watched a video on it?". There were also exercises that used to be completed during off site training that needed to be done. I was finally told by management about them roughly 3 months in and that I needed to get them done, only to get a scathing email 3 days later from my manager asking why he was getting emails that I was overdue in completing them and that I needed to work on them on my time off.

Interview - Extremely fast interview where things were not fleshed out like they should be. I asked one question in particular about the hands on/physical needs of the job, and was told there were none, only to spend 3 weeks climbing over a delivery truck learning the inspection process. It was also explained to me during the interview that long hours would happen once "peak season" started, which is November through January. Image my surprise when I was working 12 or more hours a day, into the early hours, sometimes until the sun came up, only to be expected to be on a management call everyday at 3pm. FYI, the interview lasted less than 30 minutes.

The Work Itself - The work itself is high stress. If you are based out of the main hub, you have to deal with all the shop technicians, the phone constantly ringing from either other area shops looking for parts or drivers on the road that have broken down in one way or another, or a constant parade of drivers coming into the office to ask about the status of the truck they normally drive. If you are assigned to the satellite centers, you are constantly on the road going to them or trying to help those techs over the phone even though you might be a couple of hours away...if you are actually allowed to do the job. I spent more time at the main hub subbing for other supervisors that were on vacation or off of work for whatever reason, that I was constantly falling behind on my duties, which of course, came with either a scathing email, or a phone call about the fact I was not doing my job correctly. My favorite was once when I was already up, showered, and ready to head out the door, only to have the manager contact me to let me know I was needed at the main hub to work the 9pm-5am shift, so I had to try to go back to bed so I could stay up until the sun came up the next morning.
